concepts.title: Sound Generation and Vibration
concepts.content: Sound is generated by the rhythmic vibration of any object. Vibration of an object is necessary for generation of sound.

examples.text: Swung the clapper of the bell

keyPoints: Sound is generated by rhythmic vibration of any object
Vibration is necessary for sound generation
Sound reaches us by travelling through some medium
You can feel vibrations by touching a ringing mobile or speaker
concepts.funFact: üí° When a singer tunes a tanpura, they adjust the tension in its strings to change the pitch!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 118: Let's Recall & Use your brain power

concepts.title: Oscillator, Oscillation and Oscillatory Motion
concepts.content: A swing that moves back and forth is an oscillator. When the swing moves from one end to the other and returns to its starting point, it is said to have completed one oscillation. The back and forth motion of an oscillator on either side of a central position is called oscillatory motion.
keyPoints: Oscillator: Object that moves back and forth
One oscillation = Complete back and forth movement
Oscillatory motion: Movement on either side of central position
Elasticity causes rubber band to vibrate when stretched and released
concepts.funFact: üåç Earth's gravitation is at work while the pendulum oscillates!

concepts.title: Time Period and Frequency
concepts.content: The time required by an oscillator to complete one oscillation is called the time period of the oscillator. Frequency (n) = 1/time period of oscillation (T) = 1/T. Frequency is the number of oscillations occurring in one second.
keyPoints: Time Period (T): Time for one complete oscillation
Frequency (n) = 1/T
Unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz)
1 Hz = one oscillation in one second
100 Hz = hundred oscillations in one second
concepts.funFact: üéº In Indian music, Sa, Re, Ga, Ma, Pa, Dha, Ni are of increasingly higher pitch (frequency)!

concepts.title: High and Low Pitch of Sound & Intensity
concepts.content: The pitch of a sound depends upon its frequency. Loudness or softness of sound is indicated by intensity of sound and sound level. The decibel (dB) is the unit for measuring sound level.
keyPoints: Pitch depends on frequency of sound
Sound level is measured in decibels (dB)
To tune an instrument is to adjust pitch
Tabla player tunes by hammering pegs to adjust tension
Changing wire tension changes pitch
concepts.funFact: üé∫ A harmonium accompanist finds out beforehand the key in which the singer will sing!

concepts.title: Audible, Infrasonic and Ultrasonic Sound
concepts.content: The frequency of sound audible to human beings is between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz. Infrasonic sound has frequency less than 20 Hz. Ultrasonic sound has frequency higher than 20,000 Hz.
keyPoints: Audible sound: 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (human hearing range)
Infrasonic sound: Less than 20 Hz (whales, elephants)
Ultrasonic sound: More than 20,000 Hz
Uses: Clean ornaments, observe internal organs, detect tumours
SONAR: Sound Navigation And Ranging - locate seabed/ships
Used in RADAR systems and to kill microbes/insects
concepts.funFact: ü¶á Bats maneuver during night using ultrasonic sounds they produce!

test.question: Sound is generated by the _____ of any object.
test.explanation: Sound is produced when objects vibrate rhythmically. This is the exact textbook definition from Page 118.

test.question: The unit of frequency is _____.
test.explanation: Frequency is measured in Hertz (Hz). One Hertz means one oscillation per second.

test.question: The unit used for measuring the level of sound is _____.
test.explanation: The decibel (dB) is the unit for measuring sound level or loudness.

test.question: What is the relationship between frequency and time period?
test.explanation: The formula is n = 1/T, where n is frequency and T is time period. This is directly from the textbook.

test.question: Sound needs _____ to travel from one place to another.
test.explanation: Sound requires a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. It cannot travel through vacuum.

test.question: The pitch of sound depends on its _____.
test.explanation: Pitch is determined by frequency. Higher frequency means higher pitch, as stated on Page 123.

test.question: When a pendulum completes one back and forth motion, it is called _____.
test.explanation: One complete back and forth motion is called one oscillation, as defined on Page 119.

test.question: Sound with frequency less than 20 Hz is called _____.
test.explanation: Infrasonic sound has frequency below 20 Hz, which is below the human hearing range.

test.question: The frequency range of audible sound for humans is _____.
test.explanation: Human ears can detect sounds between 20 Hz and 20,000 Hz. This is the audible range.

test.question: SONAR uses which type of sound waves?
test.explanation: SONAR (Sound Navigation And Ranging) uses ultrasonic sound waves to locate objects underwater.

keyConcepts: Sound is produced by vibrations of objects
Sound requires a medium to travel (cannot travel in vacuum)
Frequency is the number of oscillations per second, measured in Hertz
Time period is the time for one complete oscillation
Pitch depends on frequency - higher frequency means higher pitch
Sound level (loudness) is measured in decibels (dB)
commonMisconceptions: Sound can travel in vacuum - FALSE (needs a medium)
Pitch and loudness are the same - FALSE (pitch relates to frequency, loudness to amplitude/intensity)
All sounds are audible to humans - FALSE (only 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz)
Frequency and time period are directly proportional - FALSE (inversely related: n = 1/T)
Ultrasonic means very loud - FALSE (it means very high frequency)
realWorldExamples: Mumbai local train horn - loud sound around 100-110 dB
Tabla and tanpura in Indian classical music - adjusting tension changes pitch
Temple bells and mosque azaan - sound traveling through air
Diwali firecrackers - very loud sounds up to 150 dB
Harmonium accompanist tuning to singer's key
Elephants using infrasonic sounds to communicate over long distances
Bats using ultrasonic sounds for navigation at night
Medical ultrasound for seeing inside the body
SONAR in ships to detect depth and objects underwater

formulas.explanation: Frequency (n) equals one divided by time period (T). If time period is 0.1 seconds, frequency is 1/0.1 = 10 Hz
Time period (T) equals one divided by frequency (n). If frequency is 50 Hz, time period is 1/50 = 0.02 seconds
